Dear Ms. Pettway:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at 517-243-9743.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (c) Dates and places of contacts, names
of persons interviewed, and names of the
interviewers. If children are interviewed,
their last names may not be included in
the report.
One of one special evaluations reviewed included the foster child’s first and last
name.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:

• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
Two of six foster children case files reviewed had updated service plans that were
late.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Interim, CAP approved 1/17/2024
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of one independent living case files reviewed did not have documentation
the agreement was signed and dated by the youth and social service worker once
every 90 days.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
• (1) An agency social service worker shall
complete a written adoptive evaluation within 90
days of the family signing an adoption
application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
Two of three adoptive family case files reviewed found the adoptive family
evaluations were passed the 90 day requirements upon the family signing the
application.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Medical Passports: Per clarification from the DHHS policy/contract office,
Medical Passports must be generated and saved in MiSACWIS quarterly for
every foster care youth. Regardless of whether signatures are required by
parents or foster parents.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the individual CAP is as follows: The agency
submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the interim
inspection completed on 12/19/2023, with the corrective action plan approved on
1/17/2024. The agency received a citation with rules 400.112212, 400.12418 (a)
& (b), FOM 722-08D & FOM 801-03. The agency has one repeat violation during
this reporting period for Rule 400.12418 (b). Additional corrective action is
required to reduce this violation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed onsite on
9/17/2024. The Chief Administrator (CA) identified barriers as staff were leaving
child welfare due to the abundance of stress in working in child welfare agencies.
The agency had four resignations; two supervisors left without any notifications
and three staff were terminated. New staff were hired but the CA stated it takes
time to learn the process. The CA reported she reviewed past inspections and
have concluded the reason there are repeat violations is because management is
not following through on what was decided upon in previous CAPs. She stated
she will be more proactive and will monitor more closely throughout the year.

Financial Overview
The agency provided a copy of their audit completed by an independent certified
accountant dated 9/30/2022 and presented to the agency on 8/11/2023. The
agency also provided their annual budget. No concerns were noted.
Staff Interviews:
Interviews were conducted with three staff onsite. Staff reported feeling supported
by their supervisors, coworkers, and the administration. They all reported the
work environment is positive. However, staff were all consistent in stating that
Child Welfare Training Institute (CWTI) is a good base for training, but it lacks
informing the staff what to expect when cases are assigned. Staff were consistent
in stating the agency needs a training model for new hires with forms that is
needed with case records. Staff reported its difficult working, not knowing exactly
what to do with a case file and what forms are needed when their supervisors are
new to the environment as well or newly promoted.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have adequate space and equipment to perform required
job duties. Files are stored securely and in a manner that provides unauthorized
access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one Safety Alert:
Safety Alert:
There were two pools with no barriers, smoke detectors were only located by the
bedrooms, medication was not properly stored, lock was broken where chemicals
are stored and seven dogs and two cats in the home were without vaccinations.
Resolution:
As of 8/14/2024, all areas of safety concerns have been addressed and corrected.
Water was removed from both pools, three new additional smoke detectors have
been installed, medication is stored in a locked medication box, new locks installed
on cabinet doors where chemicals are stored, and seven dogs received vaccinations
on 8/8/2024. The seven dogs license applications were applied for, and payment
made to Tuscola County Treasurer. Documentation and photos are attached to the
safety alert and uploaded in CWLM.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
